aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Beech C23 in Augusta, Kansas
A flight instructor and student pilot were performing a soft field takeoff from a 2,340 foot grass runway.
The Beech C23 aircraft did not accelerate as expected during takeoff.
The aircraft lifted off during the takeoff attempt.
Trees at the end of the runway were approaching quickly as the aircraft lifted off.
The flight instructor made a slight turn to the right, aiming for shorter trees.
The Beech C23 did not climb out of ground effect.
The aircraft struck a barbed wire fence.
The aircraft impacted the ground just beyond the fence.
The aircraft came to a stop in the upright position.
The accident occurred on July 20, 2013, at 10:30 Local time.
The accident location was Augusta, Kansas.
The aircraft registration was N377TT.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage to its fuselage and wings.
Neither the flight instructor nor the student pilot were injured in the accident.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was CEN13CA423.
The Pilot Operating Handbook indicated the aircraft would have a 1,700 foot ground roll on grass field.
The Pilot Operating Handbook indicated the aircraft would need 2,827 feet to clear a 50 foot obstacle.
The Pilot Operating Handbook calculations were based on grass field, no wind, flaps up, 2000 feet mean sea level, and 88 degree Fahrenheit.
The flight instructor stated the aircraft did not perform as the Pilot Operating Handbook indicated.
The soft field takeoff technique involved having flaps extended and a nose high attitude.
The aircraft likely did not reach the grass field performance indicated in the Pilot Operating Handbook.
The soft field technique, nose high attitude, and over-rotation of the nose likely degraded the aircraft's takeoff performance.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot not obtaining adequate airspeed and clearance from obstructions during a grass field takeoff.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Augusta, Kansas

## Date & Time: 
July 20, 2013, 10:30 Local

## Aircraft:
Beech C23

## Defining Event:
Collision during takeoff/land

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
CEN13CA423

## Registration:
N377TT

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 None

## Analysis

The flight instructor and student pilot were performing a soft field takeoff from a 2,340 foot grass runway. During the takeoff the airplane did not accelerate as expected. The flight instructor stated that the airplane lifted off, but the trees at the end of the runway were approaching quickly. The instructor then made a slight turn, aiming for some shorter trees to the right. The airplane did not climb out of ground effect and struck a barbed wire fence. The airplane then impacted the ground just beyond the fence and came to a stop in the upright position. Examination of the airplane revealed substantial damage to the airplane's fuselage and wings. A review of the airplane's Pilot Operating Handbook (POH) indicated from grass field, no wind, flaps up, 2000 feet mean sea level, and 88 degree Fahrenheit, the airplane would have a 1,700 foot ground roll and would need 2,827 feet to clear a 50 foot obstacle. The instructor added that the airplane did not perform as the POH indicated. Based on a soft field takeoff technique of having flaps extended and nose high attitude, it's likely the airplane did not reach the grass field performance data indicated in the POH. The soft field, nose high attitude and an over rotation of the nose, to compensate for the rapidly approaching runway end, likely degraded the airplane's takeoff performance.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:The pilot did not obtain adequate airspeed and clearance from obstructions during a grass field takeoff.

---
